titleStmt.title: Regulatory hubs and strategies for improving heavy metal tolerance in plants: Chemical messengers, omics and genetic engineering

analytic.title: Regulatory hubs and strategies for improving heavy metal tolerance in plants: Chemical messengers, omics and genetic engineering

biblStruct.note: Received 16 January 2021; Accepted 3 May 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Chemical messengers Genome editing Genetic engineering Metal tolerance Omics

abstract.p: Heavy metal (HM) accumulation in the agricultural soil and its toxicity is a major threat for plant growth and development. HMs disrupt functional integrity of the plants, induces altered phenological and physiological responses and slashes down qualitative crop yield. Chemical messengers such as phytohormones, plant growth regulators and gasotransmitters play a crucial role in regulating plant growth and development under metal toxicity in plants. Understanding the intricate network of these chemical messengers as well as interactions of genes/metabolites/proteins associated with HM toxicity in plants is necessary for deciphering insights into the regulatory circuit involved in HM tolerance. The present review describes (a) the role of chemical messengers in HM-induced toxicity mitigation, (b) possible crosstalk between phytohormones and other signaling cascades involved in plants HM tolerance and (c) the recent advancements in biotechnological interventions including genetic engineering, genome editing and omics approaches to provide a step ahead in making of improved plant against HM toxicities.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Uncontrolled anthropogenic activities, rapid industrialization, and modern agronomic practices have polluted agricultural land with excess of heavy metals (HMs) that has resulted in a concern for agri-food system (Anjum et al., 2015). Contaminated agricultural soil is the primary source of HMs from which they are taken up by the plants along with water and minerals (Awa and Hadibarata, 2020). Although some of the metals act as nutrients for the plant and impart important physiological and biochemical roles in plant growth (Ivanov et al., 2016;Einhardt et al., 2020, Dos Santos Silva et al., 2020. Still accumulation of HMs above an optimal concentration causes highly toxic effects and damage plants survival (Chong-qing et al., 2013;Tiwari and Lata, 2018). HMs toxicity adversely affects plant physiological and molecular processes and hamper their growth and development (Khan et al., 2014;Ebbs et al., 2015;Huihui et al., 2020). Excess concentration of HMs disrupt redox balance through overproduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS), causes modifications in biomolecules, cell growth and differentiation (Singh et al., 2015;Rui et al., 2016). HM stress also inactivates different antioxidant enzymes such as superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), glutathione reductase (GR) and ascorbate peroxidase (APX), causes protein misfolding, alters membrane integrity and causes genotoxic damage by altering the expression of several genes at transcriptional levels (Khan and Khan, 2014;Dutta et al., 2018;Ghori et al., 2019, Fig. 1).

Plants avoid or resist the detrimental effects of HM toxicity by adapting a strategic series of several physiological, biochemical and molecular alterations (Fatima et al., 2020;Kaur et al., 2020;Khan et al., 2020a;AbdElgawad et al., 2020). Accumulation of HMs also induces the expression of several stress responsive genes, for instance PHYTOCHE-LATIN SYNTHASE (PCS), metallothioneins (MTs) and proteins that mediate stress tolerance and plant growth (Hwang et al., 2017;Thakur et al., 2019). Besides, plants combat HM toxicity via several signalling molecules including phytohormones, plant growth regulators (PGRs) and gasotransmitters (Asgher et al., 2015;Saleem et al., 2020). Phytohormones such as auxin (Demecsová et al., 2020), cytokinin (CK, Sytar et al., 2019), gibberellic acid (GA, Saleem et al., 2020), abscisic acid (ABA, Li and Song, 2020) and ethylene (ET; Thao et al., 2015;Khan et al., 2020a;Wang et al., 2020) acts as signaling molecules, and regulates various physiological and molecular processes and accounts for HM tolerance in plants (Asgher et al., 2015;Wang et al., 2016;Chu et al., 2020). Additionally, gaseous molecules in the plants such as nitric oxide (NO), carbon monoxide (CO), methane (CH 4 ) and hydrogen sulphide (H 2 S) also known as gasotransmitters are critically involved in HM stress responses in plants (Wang et al., 2019;Shivaraj et al., 2019: Nazir et al., 2020. Other signaling molecules such as ROS, NO, H 2 S, and calcium (Ca 2+ ) are some of the important components of intricate signalling networks that involved in response to HM toxicity in plants (Jalmi et al., 2018). Additionally, sequestration of HM is also mediated by organic acids such as citrate and malate, metal binding ligands such as phytochelatins (PCs) and glutathione (GSH; Pál et al., 2018).

For global food security, new and advanced strategies have been adapted by the researchers to produce metal tolerant plants (Banerjee and Roychoudhury, 2019;Sedeek et al., 2019). In this context, developing transgenics and use of genome editing tools have been exploited in plants under HM stress (Renau-Morata et al., 2017;Ye et al., 2017;Zhu et al., 2020). The identification and characterization of genes, proteins Fig. 1. (A) Heavy metal toxicity adversely affects morpho-physiological traits. (B) Under HM toxicity, various stress-responsive signalling cascade activated and aid in coping with the toxic adversities of HM stress. Chemical messengers such as phytohormones, plant growth regulators, gasotransmitters and other plant signaling molecules (ROS and Ca 2+ ) act as the major regulator of HM stress. Additionally, all these cascades activate stress-responsive genes to reduce HM toxicity in plants. (C) Genetic manipulation of genes/proteins/metabolite associated with HM tolerance for development of tolerant plants using omics approaches that may provide genes for developing hyperaccumulators of HM. and metabolites for HM tolerance in plants using omics tools provides the backbone for the production of transgenics with enhanced tolerance to HMs. The present review consolidates (a) major possible HM stress mitigation strategies adapted by plants with a special reference to chemical messengers (plant hormones, PGRs and gasotransmitters) (b) intricate network of phytohormonal crosstalk in support of the plant response HM toxicity (c) recent advancements in development of hyperaccumulator crops using genome editing and omic tools including genomics, proteomics and metabolomics.

div.head: Controlling heavy metal toxicity through chemical messengers
div.p: Phytohormones are chemical messengers that regulates several developmental and cellular processes, coordinate network of signalling pathways, and crucially mediates abiotic stress tolerance responses in plants (Mohan et al., 2016;Khan et al. 2019Khan et al. , 2020b. Phytohormones play regulatory role in plant growth and development and exogenous application of these phytohormones may also activate phytohormonal crosstalk within the plant during HM stress (Sytar et al., 2019;Khan et al., 2019). It has been reported that accumulation of HMs in plants modulate the transportation, distribution, endogenous concentration, and conjugation of phytohormones to mitigate HM stress responses in plants (Luo et al., 2016;Ashfaque et al., 2020).

div.head: Heavy metals and auxin
div.p: The classical phytohormone auxin plays a regulatory role in plant growth and development. The concentration and distribution of auxin alters in response to exposure of HMs such as Zn, cadmium (Cd), lead (Pb) and copper (Cu) (Luo et al., 2016). Auxin helps in detoxification mechanism and prevents oxidative damage by reducing excess ROS accumulation in plants caused due to metalloid toxicity (Singh et al., 2021). On exposure to detrimental levels of HMs, transcript abundances of several auxin responsive genes get altered along with the activation of a feedback auxin homeostasis pathway to maintain auxin levels in plants for enhanced adaptability to HM toxicity (Wang et al., 2015a). Plant roots are the primary organ that is exposed to soil contaminated with HMs and thus act as an essential criterion to be characterized for deciphering HM stress signalling and perception. Auxin plays an important role in regulating root architecture as inferred by the increased Cd sensitivity of AUX1 mutants (osAUX1) in rice (Oryza sativa) that resulted in enhanced reduction of primary and lateral root system while the exogenous application of analogue of auxin reversed the Cd induced adversities in plants (Yu et al., 2015). Auxin transporter i.e., AUX1 regulates auxin transport and signalling and influences cell division and elongation that ultimately affects root growth under arsenite stress (Krishnamurthy and Rathinasabapathi, 2013). The role of auxin in mitigating arsenic (As) stress and enhancing plant growth was speculated by the altered levels of miR319, miR854 and miR167 transcripts associated with sulphur metabolism and assimilation, and hormonal biosynthesis on exogenous application of indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) with jasmonic acid (JA) during As metal toxicity in Indian mustard (Brassica juncea); Srivastava et al., 2013). Auxin mediated growth promotion in stressed plants can also be used for phytoextraction purposes as exogenous application of auxin in combination with chelating agents such as EDTA and ethylene diamine disuccinic acid (EDDS) influences the Pb and Zn uptake thereby altering metal concentration in the plants (López et al., 2005;Fassler et al., 2010). Studies demonstrates the role of auxin in phytoextraction of HMs to improve plant growth. Combined application of IAA and Se to As stressed rice mitigate detrimental effects of As in rice plant and reduce genotoxicity of HM (Pandey and Gupta, 2015). Role of auxin in phytoextraction of HMs such as Pb and Zn was observed in sunflower (Helianthus annuus) where the exogenous supplementation of IAA in various concentrations (0-10 − 9 M) significantly reduced metals-induced adversities in plant growth and development (Fassler et al., 2010). Despite of substantial process in studies related to auxin mediated HM tolerance, challenging aspects of auxin-mediated HM tolerance need to be explored.

div.head: Heavy metals and cytokinin
div.p: Besides, CK also plays an important role in mediating plant growth and development during several abiotic stress conditions such as salinity, drought and HM toxicity (Singh et al., 2018).

A N6-prenylated adenine derivative, CK is an effective growth regulator that is synthesized in the roots, seeds and young fruits (Sakakibara, 2006) and inhibits the development of lateral root system via the repression of PIN genes (Laplaze et al., 2007). Exogenous application of CK resulted in mitigation of HM stress in commercially important plants such as maize (Zea mays), tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) and eggplant (Solanum melongena; Singh and Prasad, 2014;Singh et al., 2018). CK plays an important role in As metal detoxification as there exists a linear correlation between enhanced expression of cytokinin oxidase/dehydrogease 1 (CKX1) and the decrease in CK level that further leads to accumulation of PCs and GSH (Mohan et al., 2016). Moreover, it has also been reported that the exposure of CK precursor kinetin increased the net photosynthetic rate, content of chlorophyll and growth rate in Cd stressed pea (Pisum sativum) seedlings (Al-Hakimi, 2007). Exogenous application of CK-mitigated Zn stress-induced senescence in halophytes such as Southern Seashore Mallow (Kosteletzkya pentacarpos), enhanced net photosynthesis, stomatal conductance and stem length with HM resistance however, the efficiency of CK in mitigating Zn stress was reduced in presence of NaCl (Zhou et al., 2019). Singh and Prasad (2014) showed that the foliar supplementation of kinetin (an artificial CK; 10 μM) alleviates Cd stress adversities enhanced antioxidative capacity by accelerating the activities of SOD, GST, CAT and peroxidase (POD) and strengthened photosynthetic machinery in eggplant seedlings. Exogenous application of CK (10 μM) mitigated Cd induced damages in plant tissues, improved plant growth and enhanced the activity of enzymatic antioxidants including APX, GR, dehydroascorbate reductase (DHAR), and monodehydroascorbate reductase (MDHAR) as well as non-enzymatic antioxidants such as ascorbate + DHA and GSH + glutathione disulfide (GSSG) in tomato seedlings (Singh et al., 2018). However, the action of CK on HM stress mitigation in plants is yet not known well, therefore further insights into researches based on CK-mediated HM stress tolerance could help in developing HM tolerant plants.

div.head: Heavy metals and gibberellins
div.p: Phytohormone, GA is a tetracyclic diterpenoid that also has a pivotal role in the governing physiological and molecular processes in plants (Yamaguchi, 2008). Among its role as an important chemical messenger in plants during abiotic stresses (Niharika and Singh, 2021b), GA-mediated regulation of plant growth during HM toxicity is an interesting aspect to be discussed. GA mediates plant growth and development during HM stress conditions by ameliorating membrane integrity, changing source-sink dynamics, influencing cell division processes and by improving detoxification mechanism in plants (Iqbal et al., 2011;Emamverdian et al., 2020). Exogenous application of GA 3 counteracted the Pb and Cd induced damages in broad bean (Vicia faba), improved mitotic activity, yielded seed protein and RNA contents and carbohydrate metabolism (Mansour and Kamel, 2005). During Cd stress condition, exogenous supplementation of GA (5 μM) alleviated Cd toxicity induced adversities in Arabidopsis plant by repressing the activity of iron regulated transporters (IRT1) that also enhance Cd uptake in plants (Zhu et al., 2012). GA has shown its functional interplay with Ca 2+ signalling pathway that further aid in amelioration of HM tolerance in plants. Application of GA in combination with Ca 2+ to nickel (Ni)-stressed wheat (Triticum aestivum) significantly improved plant traits such as height, biomass, dry weight, chlorophyll content, activity of antioxidant enzymes along with enhanced proline content (Siddiqui et al., 2011). Combined application of phytohormones such as GA and IAA (5 mM) along with proline (10 mM) and compost (40 t ha − 1 ) significantly mitigated Pb stress in maize (Adejumo et al., 2020). The application of GA also reversed the toxic effects of Cr on plant growth and ammonium assimilation in pea seedlings by the upregulating the activity of antioxidant system and maintaining redox balance (Gangwar et al., 2011). Exogenous application of GA also alleviated Cd-induced toxic effects on growth and germination of seeds of rapeseed (Brassica napus; Meng et al., 2009) and Cd and Pb-induced adversities in broad bean and lupin plants (Lupinus albus; Sharaf et al., 2009). Thus, it can be inferred that GA is an integral component of HM stress elevating machinery modulating plants developmental and physiological responses during HM stress for sustaining the survival of plants.

div.head: Heavy metals and abscisic acid
div.p: The carotenoid derivative ABA plays a pivotal role in several plant growth processes and in responses against the different environmental stresses. ABA is considered as an important regulator of plants responses to HM toxicity and is accumulated during HM stress due to the upregulation of ABA biosynthesis genes (Bücker-Neto et al., 2017). Accumulation of Cd and Si significantly alters endogenous ABA levels as reported in common reed (Phragmites australis; Fediuc et al., 2005), rice (Kim et al., 2014) and rapeseed (Brassica napus; Yan et al., 2016). Increased level of endogenous ABA was also reported in chickpea seedlings grown under Zn and Pb stress (Atici et al., 2005).

The transcriptomic analysis revealed the enhanced expression of genes responsible for the ABA metabolism in rice grown under As (arsenite and arsenate) stressed rice plants (Chakrabarty et al., 2009). Under As toxicity, the genes involved in ABA biosynthesis and its signalling such as OsPP2Cs, OsbZIP10 (OsABI5), OsbZIP12 (OsABF1), Osb-ZIP66 (OsABF5), and OsbZIP72 (OsABF4) are induced in rice plants (Huang et al., 2012;Yu et al., 2012). Moreover, the enhanced expression of 9-cis-epoxycarotenoid dioxygenase 1 (NCED1) and synthesis of ABA in response to the Cd stress in potato lead to PC accumulation while the treatment with a non-specific inhibitor of ABA biosynthesis (fluridone; Flu) significantly reduced endogenous ABA level (Stroinski et al., 2013). Interestingly, Arabidopsis plants inoculated with Rhodococcus qingshengi (ABA catabolizing bacteria) shows increase in the accumulation of Cd (72%), Zn (46%), and Ni (50%) in shoots and the increase is more pronounce in ABA sensitive mutants (abi1/hab1/abi2) and less pronounced in ABA insensitive mutant (snrk 2.2/2.3) (Lu et al., 2020a).

ABA supplementation reduces metal toxicity in Ni stressed rice plants Rubio et al., (1994), reduces Cd levels in Cd stressed Arabidopsis and Euphrates poplar (Populus euphratica; Fan et al., 2014;Han et al., 2016). It has been also reported that the exogenous supplementation of ABA to Populus x Canescens reduces Zn concentration via the downregulation of genes associated with Zn uptake and detoxification (Shi et al., 2015). ABA mediates three major pathways that include inhibition of the uptake, altering the translocation from root to shoot, and promoting the conjugation with chelators under HM (Hu et al., 2020). The Cu-induced enhanced level of ABA led to the accumulation of osmolytes such as proline and reduction in ROS scavenging in plants (Chen et al., 2001;Sharma and Dietz, 2006). ABA-induced C 2 H 2 transcriptional factor AtZAT6 and StbZIP activates the expression of several PCs biosynthesis genes including GSH1, GSH2, PCS1, and PCS2 in response to Cd stress (Stroinski et al., 2013;Chen et al., 2016). Transcriptional factors of basic region leucine zipper (bZIP) subfamily also activated PCS transcription in Gray poplar (Populus × canescens) in response to exogenously supplemented ABA (Shi et al., 2019). Rubio et al. (1994) showed that exogenous application of ABA hinders the transport of Cd and Ni to the shoots, resulting in a higher percentage of metals in the root. Besides, ABA pre-treatment also dramatically reduce Cd accumulation in the leaves of Indian mustard (Salt et al., 1995). Similarly, the exogenous application of ABA limits the root-to-shoot translocation of Cd in Arabidopsis (Perfus-Barbeoch et al., 2002). Also, less Cd accumulation was detected in parallel to reduced transpiration rate and stomatal closure with up to 100 μM ABA treatment in Indian mustard, rice and Arabidopsis (Arabidopsis helleri; Salt et al., 1995;Zhao et al., 2006;Uraguchi et al., 2009). During Pb stress tolerance, stomatal closure and a decreased transpiration ratio were observed in the pea leaves with Pb exposure parallel to elevated amount of endogenous ABA (Parys et al., 1998). Thus, it can be inferred that ABA-induced stomatal closure causes a suppression of transpiration flow and may result in a restriction of root-to-shoot translocation of metals. Several metal transporters are also believed to participate in ABA induced metal translocation. For instance, the expression HMA3, Nramp1, Nramp3, and Nramp4 were upregulated in Arabidopsis incubation with ABA-catabolizing bacteria (Lu et al., 2020a). Further, Lu et al. (2020b) showed that application of ABA (20μmol/L) promotes Cd mobility from root to shoot in the Cd-hyperaccumulating ecotype (HE) of Sedum alfredii due to induced transcription of SaHMA2, SaHMA3, and SaHMA4 (plasma membrane-localized HM ATPases). In Arabidopsis, NRT1.5 (nitrate long distance transporter) plays a vital role in the root-to-shoot translocation of nitrate in Arabidopsis (Lin et al., 2008). ABA signalling seems to inhibit the expression of NRT1.5 and has no effect on NRT 1.8 that confers Cd tolerance in Arabidopsis (Li et al., 2010). In Arabidopsis, treatment with 20 μM Cd/Cd + ABA (5 μM), NRT1.5 (Nitrate transporter 1.5) responded to ABA signalling while no such response was observed in case of NRT1.8 and the lack of response by NRT1.8 towards ABA Signalling resulted in increased nitrate accumulation in the roots, thereby reducing Cd levels in the plant roots (Wang et al., 2018). Previous reports also suggest that the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signalling is induced by Cu and Cd treatment in rice (Yeh et al. 2003(Yeh et al. , 2004. Xing et al. (2008) demonstrated the ABA-dependent MKK1-mediated activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase 6 (MPK6) in regulating CATALASE1 (CAT1) expression to maintain ROS homeostasis. Additionally, PCS and PCs speculatively acts downstream of MAPK pathway in plants and human (Rigouin et al., 2013). Further, Nguyen et al. (2012) revealed ZAT10 as direct substrate for mitogen-activated protein kinase 3 (MPK3) and MPK6 in Arabidopsis. ZAT (C2H2-type zinc finger transcription factor), bZIP are also identified as potential downstream targets of MAPKs (Roelofs et al., 2008). Thus, it can be speculated that ABA induced MAPKs are involve in regulating HM stress through transcription factors (TFs). In nutshell, ABA can be considered one of the key regulators coordinating plants responses for HM tolerance.

div.head: Heavy metals and ethylene
div.p: Ethylene (ET), a gaseous molecule has a crucial role in regulating HM stress tolerance in plants (Chen et al., 2014a;Khan et al. 2015Khan et al. , 2020aThao et al., 2015). ET is involved in lateral root growth modulation and root hair development during HM stress (Remans et al., 2012) and inhibits primary root growth to attenuate HM toxicity (Montero-Palmero et al., 2014a). HM stress upregulates the activity of 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylate synthase (ACS) and 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid oxidase (ACO), the two major enzymes in ET biosynthesis that further enhances ET production (Trinh et al., 2014;Chen et al., 2014a). For instance, under Cr metal toxicity in roots of rice plant, the expression of ACS, ACO, ethylene-insensitive 3 (EIN3) and ethylene-insensitive 4 (EIN4) significantly increased leading to enhanced ET accumulation (Trinh et al., 2014). Exogenous supplementation of ET (ethephon; 200 μL L − 1 ) alleviated Zn stress in Indian mustard in terms of increased activity of antioxidants such as SOD, GSH reductase (GR) and GSH peroxidase (GPX), restored photosynthesis and nutrient homeostasis (Khan et al., 2019). Exogenously supplemented ET (ethephon) also enhanced photosynthetic potential, nitrogen use efficiency, antioxidant activity, and the accumulation of proteins and enzymes related to plant metabolism during HMs stress (Khan and Khan, 2014;Asgher et al., 2018). However, the sensitivity of mustard plants towards Cr stress increased after treatment with ET inhibitor (AgNO 3 ) that reversed stress mitigation effects and decreased proline content, increased oxidative stress and reduced plant growth. Sun et al. (2007) revealed the role of ET in inhibiting root elongation when exposed to the aluminium (Al) toxicity as revealed by the increased enzymatic activity of ACO leading to ET accumulation and inhibition of root elongation in lotus (Lotus japonicus) (Sun et al., 2007) and in Arabidopsis (Sun et al., 2010). Asgher et al. (2014) reported that ET production plays a prominent role in alleviation of Cd stress through the modulation of antioxidant machinery in mustard plant. Cd toxicity in Indian mustard leading to ET accumulation that alleviated metal toxicity by inducing sulphur assimilation-mediated GSH production that further reduced ROS accumulation, enhanced photosynthetic rates, thus increased plant survivability during Cd stress (Masood et al., 2012). Thus, it may be elucidated that ET is involved in the major regulatory circuit that mitigates HMs-induced adversities in plants.

div.head: Heavy metals and other plant growth regulators
div.p: Besides the classical phytohormones, PGRs also remediate HM toxicity in the plants and mediate their growth and survival (Wu et al., 2020;Ali and Perveen, 2020;Chen et al., 2020). Various PGRs such as salicylic acid (SA), brassinosteroids (BRs), JAs, triacantonol (TRIA), polyamines, and melatonin are identified as stress alleviators that enhance tolerance against HM toxicity (Chen et al., 2019;Sun et al., 2020, Table 1).

Salicylic acid is a phenolic compound and crucial plant growth regulator that is involved in various physiological functions in plants (Khan et al., 2015;Kohli et al., 2017). SA mitigates metal induced phytotoxicity in plants by inducing antioxidant defense and enhancing osmolyte contents (Moustafa et al., 2020). Exogenously supplemented 100 μM SA alleviated metal induced damages to membrane integrity and other stress induced adversities in rice plants during mercury (Hg) and Pb stress (Mishra and Choudhuri, 1999). In barrel medic (Medicago Truncatula) 0.2 mM of SA attenuated Hg metal toxicity by enhancing activity of antioxidants such as nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate oxidase (NADH oxidase), APX and POD in roots (Zhou et al., 2009). Additionally, exogenous application of 1 mM SA on wheat during As stress significantly reduced HM adversities, enhanced seed germination, chlorophyll and protein content (Zengin, 2015). However, acidic form of SA and sodium salicylate (NaSA) supplemented to the plant exhibit different effects under HM stress conditions. For example, application of SA (0.5 mM) and NaSA (0.5 mM) alleviated Cd stress toxicity in maize (Gondor et al., 2016). Their mode of action differed as acidic form of SA reduced Cd accumulation in leaves and exhibited enhanced levels of CAT, POD, GR, and APX, glutathione S-transferase (GST) while sodium form of SA increased PC levels in the roots and influenced GSH-related redox alterations (Gondor et al., 2016). SA also mediates the HM tolerance in plants by influencing the levels of different antioxidant metabolites such as disaccharides (trehalose and sucrose), polyphenols, flavonoids, proline, polyamines and glycine betaine (Sharma et al., 2020). Exogenous supplementation of SA (10 μM) mitigated deleterious action of manganese (Mn) toxicity and improved Mn stress tolerance in Indian mustard by enhancing proline accumulation maximally in plant leaves (about 87%), ameliorated plant-water relations, photosynthetic traits, increased activity of antioxidative enzymes such as CAT, SOD and POX as well as lowered lipid peroxidation and electrolyte leakage (Parashar et al., 2014). Application of SA (0.5 mM) on sunflower ameliorated Cu toxicity, increased accumulation of organic solutes including soluble sugars in leaves, free amino acids in stem and leaves and proline that leads HM tolerance in sunflower (El-Tayeb et al., 2006). Similarly, accumulation of phenolics and polyamines is driven by HM triggered oxidative stress and scavenges excess ROS accumulation to protect the plant from oxidative damage (Sharma et al., 2020).

Brassinosteroid is a potent PGR that has resulted in improved plant growth during HM conditions. Application of 24-epibrassinolide (24-EBL; 10 − 10 , 10 − 8 , 10 − 6 M) in Indian mustard alleviated Pb toxicity and improved germination rate, seedling growth, activities of antioxidant enzymes such as CAT, SOD, APX and POD (Soares et al., 2020). Under Pb stress in tall fescue (Festuca arundinacea), the foliar application of 24-EBL significantly reduced ROS accumulation and lipid peroxidation by increasing the activity of antioxidative enzymes including SOD, CAT and guaiacol peroxidase as well as osmolytes such as proline that further enhanced recovery of the plant from Pb stress (Zhong et al., 2020). Just like other PGRs, JA and its derivatives also remediate metal toxicity and regulates several physiological processes as well as growth and development of the plant. Lei et al. (2020) observed that Cd treatment induces the endogenous synthesis of JA and on the other hand, exogenously sourced JA alleviated Cd stress induced chlorosis of new leaves of Arabidopsis by reducing the Cd concentration in shoot and root cell sap. Furthermore, supplementation of (1, 5, 10 mM) JA to Cu-stressed alfalfa (Medicago sativa) alleviates Cu accumulation and ameliorates physiological attributes such as photosynthesis and antioxidant system (Dai et al., 2020).

Triacontanol is another important PGR that ameliorate plant growth and mitigates HM adversities as suggested by As stressed wheat plants where foliar spray application of 1 μM triacontanol enhanced plant growth parameters such as internal CO 2 levels, chlorophyll content, stomatal activity, photosynthesis, anthocyanin and flavonoid levels (Ali and Perveen, 2020). Combine application of triacontanol with NO synergistically attenuates the As toxicity in coriander seedlings by reducing electrolyte leakage, malondialdehyde (MDA) and ROS accumulation, enhancing non-enzymatic (ascorbate, GSH, phytochelatin content) and antioxidant enzymes (APX, CAT, SOD, MDHAR, DHAR, GR) activity, phenylalanine ammonia-lyase (PAL) activity, maintaining the integrity of membrane system especially in photosynthetic tissues (Asadi Karam et al., 2017a). Polyamines including spermidine show antioxidant activity and binds metal ions. Studies have revealed the role of polyamines in plant growth regulation during HM toxicity (Choudhary et al., 2012;Pál et al., 2017). For instance, putrescine exhibits defensive roles during Al toxicity to attenuate oxidative stress and inhibit the activities of polyamine oxidase (PAO) localised in cell wall and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP) oxidase localised in plasma membrane (Yu et al., 2018).

Melatonin is a natural indoleamine that significantly regulates plant growth during HM stress by stimulation of antioxidant enzymes (CAT, POD, SOD, APX, GPX) activity that mitigates oxidative damage and reduction in cell damage (Nawaz et al., 2018). Studies have revealed that melatonin alleviated HM in edible fruits such as strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch). Under As stress conditions, the foliar application of melatonin (200 μmol L − 1 ) remediated As metal pollution in strawberry by improving seedling growth, biomass, chlorophyll content, soluble protein content, antioxidant activities (CAT, APX, SOD, POD), anthocyanin content, slow senescence rate with reductions in MDA content (Wu et al., 2020).

div.head: Heavy metals and gasotransmitters
div.p: Gasotransmitters are the gaseous signalling molecules that are either synthesized endogenously in the plants or have an exogenous origin. They play a crucial role in mediating gasotransmitters such as NO (Terrón-Camero et al., 2019;Alamri et al., 2020), H 2 S (Shivaraj et al., 2019), CO (Mukherjee and Corpas, 2020), and CH 4 (Gu et al., 2018) are crucial regulatory players in mediating plants' responses to abiotic stresses cues including HM toxicity and sustain plant growth and development (Yao et al., 2019, Table 2; Fig. 3).

Nitric oxide (NO) is one of the important gasotransmitters that is produced both endogenously and derived from an exogenous origin and help in sustaining plants survivability during HM stress conditions (Terrón-Camero et al., 2019). The endogenous levels of NO elevate during plants exposure to HMs, which may be due to the alterations in NO-dependent transcript abundances (Besson-Bard et al., 2009). Exogenous application of sodium nitroprusside (SNP; source of NO, 100 μM) significantly reduced ROS accumulation, enhanced chlorophyll content and increased nutrients absorption (iron (Fe), Zn, Cu) in ryegrass (Lolium perenne) seedlings under Cd stress and enhanced stress tolerance (Chen et al., 2018b). Pre-treatment of Indian mustard seeds with NO (SNP) mitigated Cu stress induced adversities and improved seed germination rates, enhanced APX, GR and SOD activity, decreased ROS accumulation and lipid peroxidation, improved photosynthesis rate and growth potential of the plant (Rather et al., 2020a). Supplementation of SNP

Increased the activity of antioxidant enzymes and rate of germination, radicle length, reduced disturbance in membrane integrity, decreased levels of H 2 O 2 and MDA content under Cu stress conditions. Zhang et al. (2008) Wheat ( reduced high Cd toxicity and improved plant growth by upregulating antioxidant system and reducing O 2 •− (superoxide) and MDA levels in peanut (Arachis hypogaea) seedlings with enhanced contents of nutrients such as magnesium (Mg), Ca, Fe, Zn (Dong et al., 2020). NO levels negatively regulate HM uptake with Cd as an exception that positively regulates HM uptake (Terrón-Camero et al., 2019). Per et al. (2017) showed that NO mediated Cd alleviation in mustard is strongly regulated by S assimilation and GSH production. For instance, treatment of mustard plant with 100 μM SNP (NO donor) along with GSH mitigated Cd toxicity more effectively than by SNP alone in terms of reduced ROS accumulation due to enhanced antioxidant activities of APX, GR and SOD, photosynthetic rates and chlorophyll contents (Per et al., 2017). NO also alleviated Cr toxicity in tomato and enhanced seedlings vigor and seed germination by increasing proline and nitrogen content, activating several metal ligands such as ascorbate and GSH and reducing electrolyte leakage and protein carbonylation (Khan et al., 2020c). Hydrogen disulphide (H 2 S) is now considered as an important secondary messenger during plant defense signalling during HM stress (Ahmad et al., 2019;Luo et al., 2020). Exogenous supplementation of H 2 S donor (sodium hydrosulfide; NaHS) alleviated Cr stress by reducing electrolyte leakage, ROS accumulation, MDA content and ameliorated physiological and biochemical parameters such as chlorophyll content, biomass, enzymatic activity (SOD, APX, CAT, POD) in roots of cauliflower (Ahmad et al., 2019). Exogenous H 2 S supplementation (NaHS, 0.8 M) improved photochemistry of photosystem II by enhancing photochemical efficiency, photochemical quenching and quantum efficiency, enhanced photosynthetic rates and increased activity of antioxidants such as SOD, APX, GPX, GR that ultimately led to mitigation of Cu toxicity in wheat (Dai et al., 2016). Increased endogenous levels of H 2 S in rice mediated the activities of ROS detoxifying enzymes, maintained redox status of the plant, Cd homeostasis, enhanced chlorophyll biosynthesis by delivering minerals such as Mg, Mn, Zn and Fe and enhanced tolerance to Cd toxicity in rice (Mostofa et al., 2015). The production of H 2 S is also induced endogenously during HM stress as observed in alfalfa seedlings during Cd stress along with activation of its synthesizing enzyme L-cysteine desulfhydrase and D-cysteine desulfhydrase that regulate GSH metabolism and ROS homeostasis (Cui et al., 2014a). However, the exogenous application of NaHS further elevated the endogenous H 2 S levels to alleviate Cd stress induced damages characterised by maintained GSH levels and redox homeostasis in plant (Cui et al., 2014a). Combined application of both H 2 S (NaHS; 600 μM) and NO (SNP; 100 μM) significantly alleviated Co toxicity in wheat by ameliorating water content, osmotic potential, stomatal activity, carbon assimilatory rates, transpiration rate, intracellular CO 2 levels, ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RuBisCo) transcript levels and enhanced photosynthesis rate (Ozfidan-Konakci et al., 2020).

Carbon monoxide (CO) is molecular kinfolk of NO and H 2 S that triggers activation of CAT APX, guaiacol peroxidase and reduction in ROS accumulation during HM stress exposure to aid in plant growth and development (Meng et al., 2011). Besides, CO pre-treatment alleviates Cd-induced oxidative damage in alfalfa by modulating GSH metabolism, which in turn restored GSH: GSSG ratio and further decreased the oxidative damage (Han et al., 2008). Moreover, 1 μM hemin (the water-soluble CO donor) activated transcriptional expression HO-1, reduced the accumulation of Zn and this was attributed to down-regulation of Zn uptake and the expression of homeostasis-related genes (OsZIP1, OsZIP3, OsZIP7, and OsZIP8) and strengthened the Zn tolerance of rice seedlings (Chen et al., 2018c).

Another master player in re-establishing redox balance and reducing metal toxicity in plants is methane (CH 4 ) that blocks the accumulation of HMs and help in sustaining plant growth (Cui et al., 2017). In alfalfa, CH 4 may also regulate Al toxicity by maintaining nutrient balance via altered expression of transporter genes such as ALMT1, AACT, MDH1/2 and organic acid metabolism (Cui et al., 2017) and Cd toxicity by maintaining GSH and redox balance via modulations of miR159 and miR167 transcript levels and their target ABC transporters and Nramp6 (Gu et al., 2018).

An important functional interplay seems to exist between gasotransmitters also. NO and H 2 S interact with each other during HM toxicity to mitigate the adversities hindering plant growth (Shivaraj et al., 2019). Both NO and H 2 S share a part of their signalling pathways and studies have shown that H 2 S acts upstream or downstream of NO signalling pathway (Corpas et al., 2019). NO and H 2 S influences each other is output in antioxidant activity of plants (Rather et al., 2020b). Few studies suggesting a possible interplay of NO and H 2 S in mitigating HM adversities in plants. For example, during Cd stress, exogenous application of H 2 S donor molecule (NaHS; 100 μM) significantly increased NO content in alfalfa seedlings irrespective of HM conditions while the NO scavenger (cPTIO) reversed the action of H 2 S (Li et al., 2012a). Interestingly, NO and H 2 S together alleviated Pb stress adversities in sesame (Sesamum indicum) by restricting the uptake and accumulation of Pb and improved antioxidant defense machinery, improved concentration of essential nutrients such as K, Fe, Mg, P, Zn and Mn, maintained nutrient homeostasis, and ultimately improved plant growth (Amooaghaie et al., 2017). Interactive effect of NO and H 2 S on Cd stress alleviation in wheat plants was also observed by exogenous supplementation of SNP and NaHS (NO and H 2 S donors respectively) that enhanced total plant dry matter, chlorophyll content, activities of CAT, POD and SOD and essential mineral content (Kaya et al., 2020). The combined application of NO and H 2 S significantly enhanced Cd-stress alleviation by modulating ROS and osmolyte levels in bermudagrass (Cynodon dactylon; Shi et al., 2014). Moreover, both NO and H 2 S inhibitors blocked NO signals while H 2 S signals were specifically blocked by H 2 S inhibitors during Cd stress speculating the role of NO-mediated activation of H 2 S to alleviate Cd stress in bermudagrass (Shi et al., 2014). H 2 S also mitigated oxidative stress by reducing lipid peroxidation observed as decreased TBARS (thiobarbituric acid reactive substances) content. This was relatively similar to cytoprotective role of SNP (NO donor), and combined application of NaHS (100 μM) and SNP (1 mM HT) that collectively attenuated Cd stress in alfalfa seedlings highlighting the crosstalk between these two gasotransmitters (Li et al., 2012a). However, the intricate network of various gasotransmitters mediating HM tolerance is still not completely elucidated in detail and to complete this so far incomplete circuit, researches in field of gasotransmitters and their crosstalk in HM stress are continuing for their persistence.

div.head: Crosstalk of phytohormones, plant growth regulators and gasotransmitters
div.p: Single phytohormone, plant growth regulator and/or gasotransmitter during stress cues interacts with other phytohormonal pathways and other chemical messengers that assists in plants responses to HM adversities (Trinh et al., 2014;Jalmi et al., 2018, Fig. 2.). Phytohormones are involved in a crucial crosstalk with each other and with other signalling molecules such as gasotransmitters like NO, H 2 S; redox signalling and Ca 2+ to regulate growth and development in plants during HM toxicity (De Smet et al., 2015;Zhao et al., 2015;Keunen et al., 2016). Gasotransmitters such as NO, H 2 S also interact with phytohormones such as GA, CK to mediate plant responses during HM toxicity (Sadeghipour, 2017;Kolbert et al., 2019). Plant roots exposed to metal contaminated soil are the major cause of metal toxicity and modifications in root architecture is primary escape strategy adapted by the plants which involves auxin (Lešková et al., 2020). Auxin interacts synergistically with other hormones like CK to control the apical meristematic activity of root and shoot (Yang et al., 2017). Auxin, CK, ET and JA are involved in plant root remodelling/patterning on exposure to HM stress (Vanstraelen and Benková, 2012;Hentrich et al., 2013), however, an antagonistic interaction between auxin and CK also exists to control size of the root meristem (Ruzicka et al., 2009). Additionally, under Hg stress both ET and CK are speculated to regulate HM induced root inhibition (Chen et al., 2014a). ET is involved in an interplay with auxin during Al-induced root inhibition where ET biosynthesis may act as a signal to modulate auxin distribution in the roots of Arabidopsis leading to enhanced levels and distribution of auxin with Al mediated increase in AUX1 and PIN1 gene transcripts in wild type plants. However, ET biosynthesis inhibitors AVG and Co 2+ as well as antagonist of ethylene perception (Ag + ) alleviated the Al-induced root inhibition (Sun et al., 2010).

A crosstalk between ET-JA (Montero-Palmero et al., 2014b) and ET-SA (Zhang et al., 2014a) also exists under HM stress cues. For example, during Hg exposure, genes involved in JA and ET biosynthesis, as well as other genes associated with ET and JA exhibited differential expression in alfalfa, barley (Hordeum vulgare), and barrel medic (Montero-Palmero et al., 2014b). JA interacts antagonistically with ET during apical hook development in Cd-stressed Arabidopsis by downregulating HLS1, a gene that is a key modulator of auxin distribution within the roots and hook formation due to the repression of EIN3 function by a JA-activated TF MYC2 (Zhang et al., 2014b). JA signal transduction and auxin homeostasis are interlinked with each other during HM stress that is evident by alteration in expressions of auxin biosynthetic genes YUC8 and YUC9 which are also involved in JA-mediated root growth inhibition and promotion of lateral root development (Hentrich et al., 2013). An antagonistic interplay also exists between ABA and JA signalling pathways by the virtue of PYL (an ABA receptor) that activates TF MYC2 (a constituent of JA signalling) by forming a complex with JAZ to regulate plant growth and development (Chen et al., 2011). An interesting crosstalk between NO and GA that mediate plant growth during Cd stress has been described (Hasan et al., 2020). The treatment of Cd stressed mungbean (Vigna radiata) with NO modulators such as SNP (NO donor) and c-PTIO (NO scavenger) revealed that NO ameliorates GA and sulphur mediated Cd stress tolerance in plants by increasing nitrogen and sulphur use efficiency, antioxidant machinery, photosynthetic rates and growth potential of the plant (Hasan et al., 2020). Moreover, application of GA improved plant growth related traits such as inhibition of root growth, NO accumulation (Zhu et al., 2012). This study also suggested a possible of crosstalk between phytohormones such as GA with other signalling molecules such as NO in regulation of growth in HM stressed plants. Several studies have shown the possible crosstalk between the phytohormones and other gasotransmitters during HM stress (Feigl et al., 2019). For instance, in Cu 2+ stressed Arabidopsis seedlings, the lack of auxin lead to increase in NO (Peto et al., 2011) and elevated levels of NO induced root growth inhibition by reducing PIN1 dependent auxin transport (Fernández-Marco et al. 2011). Ca 2+ combated Cd stress Fig. 2. Plant growth regulators act as the chemical messengers to regulate plant responses to HM stress. ABA, ET, GA, CK auxin, JA, BR, JA regulate stress-induced expression of several stress-responsive genes to regulate plant tolerance against HM stress. toxicity by maintaining auxin homeostasis in Arabidopsis suggesting a possible crosstalk of auxin with Ca 2+ signalling molecule (Zhao et al., 2015). Besides auxin, an interplay of ET with other signalling molecules such as MAPK cascades, polyamines and NO is also speculated (Schellingen et al., 2015). Two MAPKs (MPK3 and MPK6) enhanced ET production by phosphorylating ACS2 and ACS6 (genes primarily induced during HM stress) during Cd stress in Arabidopsis (Liu and Zhang, 2004;Li et al., 2012b). Interestingly, MAPK cascade genes (MPK3/6) are also involved in JA signalling (Takahashi et al., 2007) along with the interplay of JA and SA with NO (Mur et al., 2013). Further analysis on crosstalk between various signalling molecules can therefore help in getting clearer insights into HM tolerance mechanisms in plants.

div.head: Using omics tools for understanding and developing heavy metal stress tolerant plants
div.p: In recent times, omic tools have received huge attention for its applications in mitigation programs of agricultural constraints and plant improvement. Genomics, proteomics and metabolomics have emerged as efficient tools that helps in identification of target genes, proteins and metabolites respectively, associated with HM detoxification and stress tolerance responses in plants (Fig. 1). Omic tools are successively backing up the biotechnological interventions prompted for mitigation of HM stress in plants. Recent developments in omic tools have upraised a possibility of deep exploration of events occurring in plant response to HM toxicity (Singh et al., 2016;Chaudhary et al., 2019).

div.head: Genomics and transcriptomics
div.p: Identification of stress responsive genes and deciphering their regulatory networks is an important strategy to produce stress tolerant plants. Genomics are being widely utilized to uncover the genes and their regulatory networks that are involved in plant stress responses and enhances plant growth potential (Hwang et al., 2017;Thakur et al., 2019). In recent times, numerous functional genomics studies have been conducted to identify the genes associated with HMs stress and tolerance in plants (Dubey et al., 2014;Liu et al., 2019). Genome-wide transcriptome analysis of rice roots (IR-64 cultivar) exposed to HMs stress (Cd, As, Pb and Cr) revealed the modulation in expression of commonly regulated and differentially regulated genes including some transporter genes (such as sulfate, peptide, nitrate, Zn and ABC transporters), TFs and some other genes associated with HM tolerance, out of which cytochrome P450, NAC and HSPs were mainly identified with known functions during HMs stress (Dubey et al., 2014). The expression analysis also confirmed the role of cytochrome P450 in HMs metabolism with maximal efficiency in case of Cd and Cr (VI) stress (Dubey et al., 2014). HM stress induces changes in transcriptome of the plant and thus a transcriptomic analysis of plants under different levels of stress conditions can further deepen the understanding of plant responses to HM stress (Oono et al., 2016). Hwang et al. (2017) performed a genome wide transcriptome analysis of As stressed rice plants and identified 50 candidate genes associated with As stress including genes that regulate photosynthesis, electron transport in mitochondria and lipid biosynthesis in rice plants. A comparative transcriptome analysis in roots and shoots of mustard plant revealed differential expression of a large number of genes in response to As stress (Thakur et al., 2019). Transcriptomic analysis of Purple willow (Salix purpurea) uncovered the genetic responses of the plant in terms of stress tolerance, phytoextraction and plant metabolism during As stress and revealed differential expression of genes in root, stems and leaves of the plant (Yanitch et al., 2017). Genetic mapping and transcriptional profiling of the Sorghum population consisting of 107 accessions under HMs containing water irrigation conditions revealed that pentatricopeptide repeat and zinc finger protein genes play a crucial role in phytoremediation (Hayes et al., 2013). A comparative transcriptomic analysis of viola plants with different sensitivities i.e., Viola baoshanensis (Cd hyperaccumulator) and V. inconspicua (non-tolerant) to Cd stress revealed key pathways underlying their differential tolerance to Cd stress by identification of a cascade of genes associated with sucrose metabolism, ubiquitin proteasome system, Cd compartmentalization (Shu et al., 2019). Transcriptome analysis of two rice cultivars (Bala and Azucena) with different sensitivities to As stress revealed the upregulation of 576 and downregulation of 622 transcripts leading to differential expression of TFs, stress responsive genes and transporters in which total 14 genes were stimuli to auxin responses during As toxicity (Norton et al., 2008). Transcriptomes of rice seedlings also revealed a group of stress responsive genes, transporters, MTs, heat-shock proteins, sulfate-metabolizing proteins, and other regulatory genes with altered expression that included auxin induced proteins such as PCNT115, auxin-responsive genes such as OsIAA20, OsIAA9, jasmonate Fig. 3. Gasotransmitters act as a signal to mediate plant responses during HM stress conditions. Among these molecules, NO, H S, CH 4 , and CO have been described for their involvement in HM stress acclimation responses in plants. They enhance plant growth potential through inducing physiological and biochemical traits.

O-methyltransferase, gibberellin 20 oxidase 2, gibberellin 2-beta-dioxygenase, gibberellin receptors such as GID1 and cytokinin-O-glucosyltransferase during As toxicity (As III and AsV) (Chakrabarty et al., 2009). In nutshell, genomics has established itself as an important tool for identification of genes and their regulatory pathways associated with HM tolerance in plants and manipulation of these molecular circuits may further aid in production of efficient HM tolerant varieties or hyperaccumulators.

div.head: Proteomics
div.p: Proteomics is an efficient tool to study the change in expression of proteins under varying environmental conditions that further aids in identification of key proteins underlying abiotic stress tolerance in plants. During HM stress, the native conformation of proteins also gets deformed leading to the formation of proteotoxic aggregates (Tamás et al., 2014). HM exposure specifically modulates protein patterns within the plants by altering the expression of regulatory proteins and metabolic enzymes (Aina et al., 2007). Plants maintain a functionally stable and healthy proteome to enhance their survivability during HM stress (Hasan et al., 2017). Proteome investigations in several plants such as Arabidopsis (Semane et al., 2010), rice (Lee et al., 2010), Indian mustard (Alvarez et al., 2009), have also assisted in studies related to their cellular responses of these plants during HM stress. Proteomics insights into river red gum (Eucalyptus camaldulensis) exposed to Cu stress were deciphered by the proteome profiling where increased Cu levels correlated with the expression of 26 differentially expressed proteins (11 increased and 15 decreased) including proteins involved in photosynthesis reactions, ROS detoxification, glycolysis, carbohydrate metabolism, transcription, and translation (Alotaibi et al., 2019). Proteome maps of root extracts and 2D proteomic analysis of tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum) treated with different concentrations of Cd (low; 10 microM and high; 100 μM) resulted in differential stress responses as low concentrations of Cd significantly modulated tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA) cycle, respiration and glycolytic pathway while high Cd concentration lead to carbon metabolism shutdown and enhancement of stress associated and detoxification machinery (Rodriguez-Celma et al., 2010). Root proteome analysis of Arabidopsis reveals 41 spots indicating significant alterations in abundance of proteins including GSH S-transferases, metabolic enzymes (such as glycine hydroxymethyl transferase, ATP sulphurylase, and trehalose-6-phosphate phosphatase), latex allergen-like proteins and various other proteins with unknown functions after treatment with HM Cd (Roth et al., 2006). Since, proteins are macromolecules that are directly responsible for most of the crucial biological processes and their function is directly affected by posttranslational modifications in a living cell, which cannot be identified via genome studies. Therefore, proteomic studies need to be performed, which allow us to elucidate the function of proteins in mediating plant responses against HM toxicity.

div.head: Metabolomics
div.p: Metabolomics can be considered as an efficient determinant of plant responses during HM stress, differences in protein amount and the relative protein activity within the plant often leads to changes in enzymatic activity and metabolic fluxes (Sulpice et al., 2010). HM exposure interferes with normal plant functioning and causes enzyme inhibition, metabolic disturbances, growth retardation and ultimately plant death (Sharma and Dietz, 2009). Therefore, a good understanding of the impact of HM toxicity remains incomplete without the knowledge of metabolites produced during HM stress regimes. Understanding the metabolite synthesis patterns of the plants exposed to HM stress may provide insights into comprehensive monitoring of plant responses (Villiers et al., 2011). For example, exposure to HMs (Cd and Cu) led to the changes in plant metabolome as revealed by the combined approaches of high-resolution mass spectrometry, untargeted liquid chromatography followed by all-ion fragmentation in rice (Navarro-Reig et al., 2017). In this study, a total of 97 metabolites were identified whose concentration changed due to HMs stress and affected major metabolic pathways including secondary metabolism, amino acid profiling, carbon metabolism, along with glycerophospholipid and glycolipid metabolism. Metabolite profiling of soybean revealed 42 and 19 differential metabolites in roots and leaves respectively under excess Mo stress. Among metabolites, accumulation of organic compounds (citric acid, 2-oxoarginine, gluconic acid, L-nicotine, and D-glucarate) enhanced in the roots that act as chelators against mitigate Mo toxicity and the hormonal levels (JA, SA and methyl-JA) also increased in both roots and leaves (Xu et al., 2018). Metabolite profiling of radish (Raphanus sativus) roots using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) exposed to Cd and Pb stress revealed different but overlapping metabolic changes in sugars, amino acids, inorganic and organic acids (Wang et al., 2015b). While Pb stress resulted in profound biochemical changes including carbohydrates metabolism, energy metabolism and GSH metabolism, Cd-induced major differences in energy intake, amino acids metabolism and pathways linked to oxidative phosphorylation in radish roots (Wang et al., 2015b). Mass spectrometry (MS) based determination of changes in metabolome of Indian mustard on exposure to different levels of Cd (25 μM and 100 μM) revealed that Cd stress affects energy generating metabolic pathways, GSH and PC metabolism, Calvin cycle and photorespiration metabolism (D'Alessandro et al., 2013). Thus, changes in photorespiration metabolism are an adaptive strategy of the plant to cope with Cd induced adversities including misbalanced stomatal conductivity, CO 2 depletion and oxidative stress conditions.

Metabolome analysis coupled with other omics tools may provide a better and amplified insight to the mechanisms underlying HM tolerance in plants. Dubey et al. (2010) reported that transcriptomic and metabolomic shifts were observed in rice roots during Cr (VI) toxicity and revealed the regulatory pathways underlying plant stress responses during Cr stress. The transcriptome profiling of rice roots suggested linear increase in Cr concentration in the plant roots causing metal toxicity along with the up-regulation and down-regulation of expression of 1138 and 1610 genes respectively encoding for transporter and regulatory proteins involved in plant metabolism, growth and development during metal toxicity (Dubey et al., 2010). Comparative proteome analysis coupled with metabolome analysis of the plant provide better insights into metal uptake and their translocation by highlighting the differentially expressed proteins and metabolites whose expression gets altered during HMs toxicity (Ahsan et al., 2012). Thus, omics tools have smoothened the identification of specific molecular and biochemical networks underlying HM stress responses, deciphered gene expression mechanisms, assisted in genetic engineering of specific stress related genes, proteins and metabolites, and advanced the pace for development of HM tolerant plants.

div.head: Developing heavy metal-resilient plants through genetic engineering
div.p: In order to enhance plant growth and ensure their high productivity, it is important to either reduce the accumulation of HMs within the plants or to increase plant tolerance to such metal toxicities i.e., development of hyperaccumulators (Kumari et al., 2018). The HM stress responsive genes, proteins and metabolites can be manipulated for either reducing HM accumulation or increasing plant tolerance to HM adversities. Such manipulation needs tools of genetic engineering that can be highly efficient in altering genes associated with metal acquisition, transportation, and storage inside the plant. Genetic engineering primarily involves development of tolerant varieties either by transgenics approach or by genome editing.

div.head: Transgenic approaches for development of heavy metal tolerant plants
div.p: The development of transgenics with up-regulated expression of key genes responsible for improved metal tolerance through their active involvement in regulation of plant metabolism provides insights to understand and enhance the tolerance potential of plants (Anwar and Kim, 2020). Transfer of candidate genes from plants with high tendency for hyper-accumulation of HMs is an effective strategy for production of tolerant varieties (Martínez et al., 2006). Several plants are bio-engineered for enhancing tolerance to HM stress by targeting candidate genes that are involved in metal accumulation and sequestration. For example, HM transporter genes are considered as the potential targets for genetic engineering to improve metal tolerance in plants and thus transgenic plants with manipulated efficiencies for metal transport into vacuoles can serve best for reducing the metal toxicity within cellular sites (Zhang et al., 2018). Transgenic plants with enhanced HM tolerance have been developed by genetic manipulation of the metal transporter genes such as OsMTP1 in cultivated tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum; Das et al., 2016), PgIREG1 in Arabidopsis (Merlot et al., 2014); genes encoding metal chelators (Kim et al., 2005), genes encoding MTs (Peng et al., 2017), genes associated with antioxidant machinery (Koźmińska et al., 2018). Overexpression of MhNCED3 in Arabidopsis inhibited the expression of IRT1, HMA2 and Nramp1, lead to reduced Cd uptake and root-to-shoot translocation (Zhang et al., 2019a). Many important genes families like ABC (ATP-binding cassette; encodes proteins for metal ion detoxification (Chen et al., 2017), and tonoplast localised proteins for vacuolar sequestration (Borghi et al., 2019); CDF (cation diffusion facilitator) family coding for metal tolerance proteins (MTP) and proteins for efficient metal ion sequestration (Renau-Morata et al., 2017); ZIP (ZRT/IRST-related proteins) regulate the transport of essential elements like Zn and Fe can be exploited in production of transgenic hyperaccumulators. A transgenic tobacco over-expressing OsMTP1 (rice) exhibited apparent enhancement in the Cd accumulation and greater tolerance to As stress as well along with reduced oxidative damage and cell death (Das et al., 2016). Overexpression of AtIRT1 in Arabidopsis significantly increased the Cd and Zn accumulation (Conolly et al., 2002) and overexpression of Zn transporter gene NcZNT1 from metal hyper accumulating Noccaea caerulescens in Arabidopsis resulted in enhanced accumulation of Cd and Zn (Lin et al., 2016).

The transgenic approaches for improved tolerance against the oxidative effects of metals have also been reported. Manipulating antioxidant system for maintaining redox homeostasis to prevent biomolecules degradation including DNA, proteins and lipids maintain structural and functional stability of cellular structures, transgenic hyperaccumulators may be developed (Du et al., 2019). For averting metal toxicity induced oxidative stress, transgenic plants over-expressing antioxidant genes for SOD, CAT and APX with low ROS accumulation under Cu, As and Cd stress have been developed (Guan et al., 2009;Gao et al., 2016). Moreover, improved antioxidant system in transgenic lines correlates with the overall growth performance in terms of photosynthesis (Ivanova et al., 2011), mineral uptake (Pan et al., 2020), redox homeostasis maintenance and enzyme functioning (Ivanova et al., 2011;Du et al., 2019) etc. Transgenic lines developed for over-expression attributes do not always exhibit the unique effects, however, can impart beneficial effects through their influence on the alternative tolerance mechanisms. For example, CAT deficient tobacco line (CAT1AS) exhibited lower ROS (H 2 O 2 ) concentrations by up-regulating the alternative constitutive guaiacol and APX, and reducing the NADPH oxidase-like activity reflecting to the activation of alternate mechanisms for countering the Cd stress (Iannone et al., 2015). Glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) catalyse conjugation between GSH and xenobiotics thereby contributing to radical scavenging (Hellou et al., 2012;Du et al., 2019). Transgenic alfalfa exhibiting simultaneous expression of GST and human CYP2E1 showed increased tolerance to Cd, Hg and xenobiotic trichloroethylene (Zhang and Liu, 2011;Zhang et al., 2013) suggesting the benefits of such lines in phytoremediation and crop growth maintenance against mixed metal contaminants. In addition, reduced oxidative damage in transgenic plants by improving polyamine synthesis through incorporation of MdSPDS1 gene has been shown in European pear (Pyrus communis; Wen et al., 2010).

Another key area for enhancing the metal tolerance in plants includes the PCs, which carry chelation of toxic metal ions and are enzymatically synthesized from GSH or amino acids or organic acids or MTs (Yadav, 2020). For manipulating the synthesis of PCs, it should be mentioned that only MTs have coding genes while as others (GSH, amino acids and organic acids) are regulated by the enzyme activities mediating their biosynthesis. Chen et al. (2015) have successfully transformed tobacco for improved Cd tolerance due to up-regulation of PCS from Chinese white populous (Populus tomentosa). Transgenic Arabidopsis over-expressing VsPCS exhibited greater tolerance to Cd by exhibiting significantly declined accumulation within cellular tissue due to quick chelation (Zhang et al., 2018). Tolerance to Cd and As in Arabidopsis correlated with overexpression of genes involved in PC biosynthesis (AsPCS1 and YCF1) imparting increased chelation and vacuolar sequestration of toxic metals. In another study, co-expression of PCS and glutamyl cysteine synthase genes from common reed (Phragmites australis) resulted in greater Cd tolerance in tall fescue through enhanced production of PCs, non-protein thiols and GSH (Zhao et al., 2014). Transformed plants exhibit better physiological and biochemical attributes like membrane functioning and antioxidant activity (Zhao et al., 2014;Ai et al., 2018). Ai et al. (2018) reported enhancement in the synthesis of PCs and anthocyanins imparting greater tolerance to transgenic Petunia against multiple metal toxicities including Zn, Cu, Cr and Mn due to overexpression of MYB1 from cultivated radish. MYB1 over-expressing lines exhibited improved growth and stomatal density through maintenance of relative water content (RWC), chlorophyll and antioxidant functioning. Therefore, it can be inferred that transgenic research for developing cultivars with enhanced metal tolerance has significant implications in future crop production.

div.head: Transcription factors engineering to enhance heavy metal tolerance in plants
div.p: In addition, of the above-mentioned key regulators of metal tolerance, the engineering of TFs regulating synthesis of key metabolic compounds also affects the metal tolerance. Numerous TF gene families such as ZAT6, Zinc-Finger type (Chen et al., 2016); bZIP (Huang et al., 2016); GeBP-LIKE 4 (GPL4) (Khare et al., 2017); NAC (Yuce et al., 2019); R2R3-type MYB (Zhang et al., 2019b); WRKY (Sheng et al., 2019;Cai et al., 2020) have their crucial role in HMs stress tolerance. Overexpression of bZIP TF BjCdR15 from Indian mustard enhances Cd tolerance in Arabidopsis and tobacco. BjCdR15 was found located in epidermis and vascular system and resulted in restricted transport of Cd to shoot resulting in greater accumulation within root (Farinati et al., 2010). Several dehydrins such as BjDHN2/BjDHN3 from Indian mustard, also play an important role as an antioxidant protein in tolerance against HM such as Zn and Cd in plants by maintaining their membrane stability and decreasing lipid peroxidation and (Xu et al., 2007). Du et al. (2020) showed that overexpression of AemNAC2 from Aegilops markgrafii (a wild relative of wheat) in transgenic wheat enhanced Cd stress tolerance by supressing the expression of key genes (TaNRAMP5 and TaHMA2) involved in metal absorption and transport, thereby reducing Cd levels in root, shoot and grains of the wheat plant. A MYB TF of R2R3-type i.e., SbMYB15 Salicornia brachiata alleviates Cd and Ni in transgenic tobacco in terms of improved plant growth and enhanced chlorophyll content by reducing ROS accumulation and enhanced activity of antioxidant enzymes such as CAT and SOD (Sapara et al., 2019). Another study revealed that a MYB TF, BnMYB2 (that is involved in phytohormonal signalling and various stress responses) from ramie (Boehmeria nivea) positively regulated Cd accumulation and enhanced Cd tolerance in Arabidopsis by improving fresh weight, root elongation and Cd content compared to those of WT seedlings (Zhu et al., 2020). The ectopic expression GmORG3 (a basic helix-loop-helix TF from soybean) enhanced Cd tolerance in soybean mosaic seedlings by reducing translocation of Cd from root to shoot and in tobacco by reducing Cd stress induced phytotoxic effects such as blockage in root elongation and reduced chlorophyll content and maintains Fe homeostasis (Xu et al., 2017a). In addition to that, Tiwari et al. (2020) also deciphered phytohormonal interplay with the stress induced OsMYB-R1 in elevating Cr stress in rice. It was observed that OsMYB-R1 over-expressing transgenic rice shows evident increase in lateral roots, which was speculated to be associated with, enhanced tolerance to Cr. The increase in lateral roots was correlated with a corresponding increase in auxin accumulation in transgenic lines as compared to wild type plants that further strengthens the role of lateral roots in Cr tolerance. A part from that, a significant increase in antioxidant activity and proline accumulation, which was probably mediated by SA signalling in the OsMYB-R1 over-expressing lines, were also believed to be the contributing factors underlying Cr tolerance in the transgenic rice. Thus, TFs are crucial molecular regulators that can mediate HM stress tolerance in plants and mitigate metal induced adversities to help in sustaining their growth and development. However, various other TFs from different TF families that are still largely unknown and their identification as well as their functional validation can thus be useful in generating improved plant varieties with high tolerance to HMs.

div.head: Developing heavy metal tolerant plants using genome-editing approach
div.p: The advances in genome/gene editing have recently emerged as an effective approach for crop improvement with targeted traits (Sedeek et al., 2019). In the battle of this editing tools, two major approaches have been consistently used clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat/CRISPR associated protein-9 (CRISPR/Cas9) and transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENs) with the nuclease based targeted genome editing (Svitashev, 2015;Li et al., 2012c). Targeting structural or regulatory genes via CRISPR/Cas system is an effective and robust approach for development of plants resilient to HM conditions (Zafar et al., 2020). Furthermore, TALENs expanded the scope for genome engineering (Zafar et al., 2020). Site-specific nucleases have potential for generation of targeted mutagenesis and has a high application in generation of stress tolerant crop plants (Ye et al., 2017). Rice exposed to As stress exhibited growth retardation along with increased expression of OsPT4 in hydroponic culture stressed with As hinting the role of OsPT4 in As uptake. Further CRISPR/cas system was used for evidencing the role of OsPT4 in As uptake and transport in rice and CRISPR lines (OsPT4-cr) exposed to different As concentrations (5, 25 and 50 μM) exhibited stronger resistance of CRISPR lines to As metal toxicity with enhanced root and shoot length, reduction in metal accumulation and improved plant growth (Ye et al., 2017). Similarly, OsN-ramp5 knockouts of rice produced using CRISPR/cas system alleviated Cd accumulation in rice and enhanced plant yield (Tang et al., 2017). Site targeted mutagenesis of OsNramp5 in rice plants by CRISPR/cas system results in low accumulation of toxic metals such as Cd and Mn in roots and shoots of the rice plants (Tang et al., 2017). The genome editing approaches have been adapted in plant sciences to characterize genes and associated regulatory mechanisms during HM stress. These approaches can be used in developing resilient plants or hyperaccumulators with quality growth potential during HM toxicity.

div.head: Conclusion and future prospect
div.p: Heavy metals are taken up in the form of ions from the soil via roots and retards plant growth potential leading to crop production loss. Plants acclimate to thrive in such harsh conditions by inducing expression of several stress responsive genes, proteins and metabolites; activating antioxidant machinery and sequester excess of metal ions by producing chelators such as PCs, GSH and MTs. Classical phytohormones, PGRs and gasotransmitters coordinate in several cellular and metabolic processes in the plants to mediate plant responses to HM stress adversities. Besides, there is an interesting crosstalk between phytohormones and the gasotransmitters during HM stress that means both chemical messengers are involved in a functional interplay to control plant stress responses and enhanced tolerance. Various strategies to reduce the crop loss due to metal toxicity are being adopted for production of stress resilient plants using the combined approaches of biotechnological and omics tools. However, there are still many more that remains unidentified and can be deciphered as well as manipulated using appropriate omics and genetic engineering tools to assist in development of HM resilient plants in near future.

div.head: Contribution
div.p: MIRK conceptualized the concept and all authors contributed equally in preparing the manuscript.

div.head: Declaration of competing interest
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
